# Recycled Water Regulations in California

## What is Recycled Water?
Treated wastewater that meets specific quality standards for reuse, regulated under the [SWRCB Recycled Water Policy](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/recycled_water/) and [Title 22 Recycled Water Criteria](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/water-recycling-criteria.html).

## Categories of Recycled Water

### Disinfected Tertiary
- Highest quality
- Full treatment plus filtration and disinfection
- Broadest uses allowed

### Disinfected Secondary-2.2
- Treatment to specified coliform level
- Medium-range uses

### Disinfected Secondary-23
- Basic secondary treatment with disinfection
- Limited uses

### Undisinfected Secondary
- Restricted applications only

## Allowed Uses

### Irrigation
- Landscape irrigation
- Golf courses
- Agricultural irrigation
- Cemeteries and parks

### Industrial
- Cooling towers
- Dust control
- Soil compaction
- Some manufacturing

### Groundwater Recharge
- Surface spreading
- Direct injection
- Specific permit required

## Permitting
- Regional Water Board permit required through [DDW Recycled Water Permits](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/recycledwater/)
- Engineering report
- Public notification
- Monitoring requirements

## Direct Potable Reuse
- California advancing regulations
- Highly treated recycled water
- Future drinking water source
- Strict treatment and monitoring
- The [EPA Water Reuse](https://www.epa.gov/waterreuse) program provides federal guidance on reuse practices

## Take Action

1. **Review recycled water regulations** -- Visit the [SWRCB Recycled Water Policy](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/recycled_water/) page to understand current statewide policy and requirements.
2. **Check Title 22 criteria** -- Read the [Title 22 Recycled Water Criteria](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/water-recycling-criteria.html) to learn about treatment levels and allowed uses for each category.
3. **Apply for a recycled water permit** -- Contact your Regional Water Board through the [DDW Recycled Water Permits](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/recycledwater/) portal to begin the permitting process.
4. **Learn about federal reuse standards** -- Visit [EPA Water Reuse](https://www.epa.gov/waterreuse) for national guidelines and best practices for water recycling projects.

# TMDLs (Total Maximum Daily Loads) Explained

## What is a TMDL?
- Pollution "budget" for impaired water body
- Maximum pollutant load water can receive and still meet water quality standards
- Required by Clean Water Act Section 303(d)
- Managed through the [SWRCB TMDL Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/tmdl/)

## TMDL Process

### 1. Listing
- Water body identified as impaired on the [303(d) Integrated Report](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/tmdl/integrated2014_2016.shtml)
- List updated every 2 years
- Based on monitoring data

### 2. TMDL Development
- Identify pollutant sources
- Calculate allowable load
- Allocate among sources
- Implementation plan

### 3. Implementation
- Permit requirements updated
- Best management practices
- Monitoring to track progress
- Adaptive management

## Types of TMDLs in California

### Common Pollutants
- Bacteria/pathogens
- Sediment
- Nutrients (nitrogen, phosphorus)
- Metals (mercury, copper)
- Trash
- Temperature

## How TMDLs Affect You

### Permitted Dischargers
- Effluent limits may change
- Additional BMPs required
- Monitoring obligations
- Implementation schedules

### General Public
- Cleaner water bodies over time
- Recreational improvements
- May affect development projects

## Finding TMDL Information
- Regional Board websites
- Basin Plan amendments
- [EPA TMDLs Overview](https://www.epa.gov/tmdl) provides federal context and resources

## Take Action

1. **Search for TMDLs in your area** -- Use the [SWRCB TMDL Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/tmdl/) page to find active and completed TMDLs by region and pollutant.
2. **Check the 303(d) list** -- Review the [TMDL Integrated Report](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/tmdl/integrated2014_2016.shtml) to see which water bodies near you are listed as impaired.
3. **Understand federal requirements** -- Visit [EPA TMDLs Overview](https://www.epa.gov/tmdl) for background on Clean Water Act Section 303(d) and how TMDLs are developed.
4. **Attend public hearings** -- Contact your Regional Water Board to participate in TMDL development and Basin Plan amendment hearings in your area.

# Beach Water Quality Monitoring in California

## AB 411 Beach Monitoring Program

### Requirements
- Weekly monitoring at popular beaches
- April through October
- Bacteria indicator testing
- Public notification through the [SWRCB Beach Water Quality](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/beaches/) program

### Indicators Tested
- Total coliform
- Fecal coliform
- Enterococcus

## Beach Report Card

### Heal the Bay Program
- A-F grades for beaches via the [Beach Report Card](https://healthebay.org/beach-report-card-2018/)
- Weekly updates
- Summer and winter grades
- Searchable database

### What Grades Mean
- A/B: Meet standards
- C: Some concern
- D/F: Exceed standards

## Sources of Beach Pollution

### Wet Weather
- Stormwater runoff
- Urban pollutants
- Bacteria from various sources

### Dry Weather
- Failing infrastructure
- Homeless encampments
- Bird and wildlife
- Illegal discharges

## Public Notification

### When Posted
- Exceed bacteria standards
- Sewage spill
- Storm water advisory

### Where to Find
- Posted at beach
- County health website
- [Heal the Bay Beach Report Card](https://healthebay.org/beach-report-card-2018/)
- The [EPA Beach and Recreational Water](https://www.epa.gov/beaches) program provides additional monitoring data

## Protecting Yourself
- Avoid swimming after rain
- Check postings before swimming
- Avoid runoff areas
- Shower after swimming

## Take Action

1. **Check beach grades** -- Visit the [Heal the Bay Beach Report Card](https://healthebay.org/beach-report-card-2018/) to look up water quality grades for California beaches before your next trip.
2. **Review statewide monitoring** -- Visit the [SWRCB Beach Water Quality](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/beaches/) program page for AB 411 monitoring data and beach advisory information.
3. **Check EPA resources** -- Visit [EPA Beach and Recreational Water](https://www.epa.gov/beaches) for national beach safety guidelines and water quality standards.
4. **Report pollution** -- If you see a spill or discharge at a beach, contact your local Regional Water Board or call the OES spill hotline at (800) 852-7550.

# Wetlands Protection in California

## State Wetland Policy

### No Net Loss
- State policy since 1993
- Cannot reduce wetland acreage
- Mitigation required for impacts

### 2019 State Wetland Definition
- Adopted formal definition under the [State Wetland Definition and Procedures](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cwa401/docs/2021/procedures.pdf)
- Dredge or fill discharge procedures
- Application requirements

## Federal vs State Jurisdiction

### Federal (Corps of Engineers)
- Waters of the United States
- Clean Water Act Section 404
- Recent Supreme Court changes (Sackett)

### State (Water Boards)
- All waters of the state -- broader jurisdiction under the [Wetlands and Riparian Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cwa401/wrapp/)
- Porter-Cologne Act authority

## Permit Requirements

### Activities Requiring Permit
- Dredging
- Filling
- Construction in wetlands
- Discharge to wetlands

### Application Process
1. Pre-application consultation
2. Wetland delineation
3. Alternatives analysis
4. Mitigation plan
5. Agency review

## Wetland Mitigation

### Types
- Avoidance (preferred)
- Minimization
- Compensatory mitigation
- Mitigation banking

### Ratios
- Typically 1:1 or greater
- Higher for temporal loss
- Credit for restoration

## Finding Wetland Information
- National Wetlands Inventory
- California Aquatic Resources Inventory
- Regional Board guidance through the [EPA Wetlands Protection](https://www.epa.gov/wetlands) program

## Take Action

1. **Review wetland procedures** -- Read the [State Wetland Definition and Procedures](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cwa401/docs/2021/procedures.pdf) to understand California's wetland definitions and permitting requirements.
2. **Explore the WRAPP program** -- Visit the [Wetlands and Riparian Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cwa401/wrapp/) for guidance on state wetland permits and mitigation.
3. **Check federal resources** -- Review [EPA Wetlands Protection](https://www.epa.gov/wetlands) for information on Clean Water Act Section 404 and federal permitting.
4. **Contact your Regional Board** -- For pre-application consultation, find your Regional Water Board through the [Waterboards Map](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html).

# Water Rights in California

## Types of Water Rights

### Riparian Rights
- Land adjacent to stream
- Use on riparian land only
- No permit required
- Reasonable beneficial use

### Appropriative Rights
- Divert water from source
- Use on non-riparian land okay
- Permit required from [State Water Board Water Rights Division](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterrights/)
- Priority based on date

### Groundwater Rights
- Overlying landowner rights
- Appropriative rights possible
- SGMA now regulates in many basins

### Pueblo Rights
- Certain California cities
- Historical claim to watershed
- Los Angeles, San Diego, others

## Permit Process

### New Appropriation
1. Application to State Water Board
2. Environmental review
3. Public notice and protest
4. Hearing if protested
5. Permit or denial

### Statement of Diversion
- Required for riparian users
- File with State Water Board
- Report diversion amounts

## Water Transfers

### Temporary Transfers
- One year or less
- Expedited approval
- No injury to others

### Long-Term Transfers
- More than one year
- Full review required
- Change petition filed

## Enforcement
- Unauthorized diversion illegal
- Fines and cease/desist orders
- Curtailment during drought
- Public reporting of violations

## Water Rights Database
- Search existing rights through the [eWRIMS Water Rights Database](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/upward/calwatrs/)
- Review [Water Rights Application Process](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterrights/board_decisions/adopted_orders/) decisions and orders

## Take Action

1. **Learn about water rights** -- Visit the [State Water Board Water Rights Division](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterrights/) for an overview of California's water rights system and how to file applications.
2. **Search existing rights** -- Use the [eWRIMS Water Rights Database](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/upward/calwatrs/) to look up existing water rights, permits, and licenses in your area.
3. **Review board decisions** -- Browse [Water Rights Application Process](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterrights/board_decisions/adopted_orders/) decisions for precedents relevant to your water rights questions.
4. **File a statement of diversion** -- Riparian and pre-1914 appropriative users must file a Statement of Water Diversion and Use with the State Water Board annually.

# Onsite Wastewater Treatment Systems (Septic)

## Regulation in California

### Local Agency Authority
- County environmental health typically administers
- Permits for new systems
- Operating requirements
- Inspections

### State Policy
- Statewide General Order (WDRs) under the [OWTS Policy](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/owts/)
- Local agency management programs
- Minimum standards set by [OWTS Policy document](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/owts/docs/owts_policy.pdf)

## Types of Systems

### Conventional Septic
- Tank and leach field
- Gravity flow
- Most common type

### Advanced Treatment
- Aerobic treatment units
- Sand filters
- Mound systems
- Required in sensitive areas

## When Septic Required
- No municipal sewer available
- Rural properties
- Some suburban areas
- Costs versus sewer connection

## Maintenance Requirements

### Tank Pumping
- Every 3-5 years typically
- Depends on use and size
- Prevents system failure

### Inspections
- Some counties require periodic inspections
- Real estate transaction inspections
- After reported problems

## Environmental Concerns

### Groundwater Impacts
- Nitrate contamination
- Pathogen contamination
- Near drinking water wells

### Surface Water Impacts
- Failing systems
- Near water bodies
- Nutrient loading

## Alternatives
- Sewer connection
- Community systems
- Composting toilets (limited)
- The [EPA Septic Systems](https://www.epa.gov/septic) program provides guidance on alternatives and maintenance

## Take Action

1. **Review the OWTS Policy** -- Read the [OWTS Policy](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/owts/) page for statewide minimum standards and local agency management program requirements.
2. **Download the full policy** -- Access the [OWTS Policy document (PDF)](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/owts/docs/owts_policy.pdf) for detailed technical requirements on siting, design, and operation.
3. **Check EPA guidance** -- Visit [EPA Septic Systems](https://www.epa.gov/septic) for homeowner guides on maintenance, troubleshooting, and system types.
4. **Contact your county** -- Reach out to your county environmental health department for local permit requirements, inspection schedules, and approved service providers.

# Underground Storage Tank (UST) Program

## Overview
Regulates tanks storing petroleum and hazardous substances through the [SWRCB UST Cleanup Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/ust/).

## State Board Role

### Program Oversight
- Statewide regulations
- Local agency oversight
- Cleanup oversight
- Funding administration through the [UST Cleanup Fund](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/ustcf/)

### Cleanup Fund
- Financial responsibility
- Cleanup assistance
- Orphan site fund

## Local Agency Role

### Certified Unified Program Agencies (CUPAs)
- Permit tanks
- Conduct inspections
- Enforce regulations
- Oversee cleanup

## Tank Requirements

### Equipment Standards
- Double-walled tanks
- Leak detection
- Overfill protection
- Corrosion protection

### Monitoring
- Continuous monitoring
- Monthly inspections
- Annual testing
- Record keeping

## When Leaks Occur

### Reporting
- Report to CUPA within 24 hours
- Assess extent of release
- Begin cleanup

### Cleanup Process
- Site assessment
- Remediation plan
- Cleanup implementation
- Case closure

## GeoTracker

- Online database for tracking cleanup sites
- Search all UST cases at [GeoTracker](https://geotracker.waterboards.ca.gov/)
- View reports and case status
- Public access

The [EPA Underground Storage Tanks](https://www.epa.gov/ust) program provides federal UST requirements and technical guidance.

## Take Action

1. **Search for UST sites** -- Use [GeoTracker](https://geotracker.waterboards.ca.gov/) to search for underground storage tank cleanup sites near your property or in your community.
2. **Review the UST program** -- Visit the [SWRCB UST Cleanup Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/ust/) page for program requirements, regulations, and responsible party guidance.
3. **Learn about cleanup funding** -- Check the [UST Cleanup Fund](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/ustcf/) for information on financial assistance for tank owners and operators.
4. **Check federal requirements** -- Visit [EPA Underground Storage Tanks](https://www.epa.gov/ust) for federal technical standards, leak prevention, and compliance resources.
5. **Contact your local CUPA** -- Find your local Certified Unified Program Agency for permitting, inspections, and leak reporting requirements.

# Site Cleanup Program Overview

## Types of Cleanup Sites

### Voluntary Cleanup
- Responsible parties self-initiate through the [SWRCB Site Cleanup Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/scp/)
- Regional Board oversight
- Common for property transactions

### State-Directed Cleanup
- Regional Board orders cleanup
- Enforcement if needed
- Cost recovery possible

### Federal Superfund
- Most contaminated sites
- EPA lead with state role
- National Priorities List

## Cleanup Process

### 1. Site Assessment
- Characterize contamination
- Identify sources
- Determine extent
- Assess risk

### 2. Remediation Planning
- Evaluate alternatives
- Select remedy
- Prepare workplan
- Agency approval

### 3. Remediation
- Implement cleanup
- Monitor progress
- Report results
- Adjust as needed

### 4. Closure
- Cleanup goals met
- Agency verification
- Case closure letter
- Land use restrictions if needed

## Common Cleanup Technologies

### Soil
- Excavation and disposal
- Soil vapor extraction
- Bioremediation
- Thermal treatment

### Groundwater
- Pump and treat
- In-situ treatment
- Monitored natural attenuation
- Permeable reactive barriers

## Finding Site Information
- [GeoTracker](https://geotracker.waterboards.ca.gov/) database for Water Board-regulated cleanup sites
- EnviroStor (DTSC sites)
- Regional Board records through [Cleanup Sites in California](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/site_cleanup_program/)

## Take Action

1. **Search for cleanup sites** -- Use the [GeoTracker](https://geotracker.waterboards.ca.gov/) database to search for active and closed cleanup sites near your property.
2. **Review the SCP program** -- Visit the [SWRCB Site Cleanup Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/scp/) page for information on voluntary cleanup, responsible party requirements, and case closure.
3. **Check additional databases** -- Browse [Cleanup Sites in California](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/site_cleanup_program/) for Regional Board-level cleanup information and contacts.
4. **Contact your Regional Board** -- For questions about a specific site, find your Regional Water Board at the [Waterboards Map](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html) and request public records.
